articles.headline: Abbott Signs Law Allowing Texas to Arrest Migrants, Setting Up Federal Showdown
articles.snippet: The new law, which takes effect in March, could bring in mass arrests and a court fight between Texas and the federal government over immigration powers.
articles.abstract: The new law, which takes effect in March, could bring in mass arrests and a court fight between Texas and the federal government over immigration powers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Gov. Greg Abbott on Monday escalated his challenge of President Biden’s border policies by signing a measure that allows Texas law enforcement officials to arrest migrants who enter the state from Mexico without legal authorization, setting the stage for a showdown with the federal government.

articles.headline: U.S. Urges Israel to Do More to Spare Civilians in Gaza and Pushes Hostage Talks
articles.snippet: The American defense secretary reiterated “unshakable” support for Israeli security, but said protecting Palestinians was a “moral duty and a strategic imperative.”
articles.abstract: The American defense secretary reiterated “unshakable” support for Israeli security, but said protecting Palestinians was a “moral duty and a strategic imperative.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Top United States officials prodded Israel on Monday to do more to protect civilians in the Gaza Strip and sought to restart talks aimed at releasing hostages as international pressure mounted on Israel to scale back its war against Hamas.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt, Julian E. Barnes and Michael Levenson

articles.headline: An Anti-L.G.B.T.Q. Law in Uganda Is Hurting the Economy
articles.snippet: Passed in May, the Anti-Homosexuality Act is harming businesses that rely on foreign travelers and trade.
articles.abstract: Passed in May, the Anti-Homosexuality Act is harming businesses that rely on foreign travelers and trade.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sitting on a sofa in his tiny office, Simon Azarwagye, the owner of a travel company called Azas Safaris, points to numbers on his laptop — visual aids for a story that still makes him miserable to tell.

articles.headline: Poll Finds Wide Disapproval of Biden on Gaza, and Little Room to Shift Gears
articles.snippet: Opinion is split between those wanting the war to end and those pressing for a definitive Israeli victory, and the divide is starkest among older and younger generations.
articles.abstract: Opinion is split between those wanting the war to end and those pressing for a definitive Israeli victory, and the divide is starkest among older and younger generations.
articles.lead_paragraph: Voters broadly disapprove of the way President Biden is handling the bloody strife between Israelis and Palestinians, a New York Times/Siena College poll has found, with younger Americans far more critical than older voters of both Israel’s conduct and the administration’s response to the war in Gaza.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Weisman, Ruth Igielnik and Alyce McFadden

articles.headline: As Office Workers Make Their Return, So Does the Lowly Cubicle
articles.snippet: Once derided as symbols of a commodified work force, cubicles are making a comeback, and workers are personalizing them and posting photos on social media.
articles.abstract: Once derided as symbols of a commodified work force, cubicles are making a comeback, and workers are personalizing them and posting photos on social media.
articles.lead_paragraph: Among office designers and architects, cubicles are rarely mentioned. The once-ubiquitous fixture, so popular in the 1980s and ’90s, has become vilified as a sign of the dehumanization of the work force. Design experts today say cubicles are a “hard no.”

articles.headline: Doing Business in the Place With America’s Highest Minimum Wage
articles.snippet: In July, West Hollywood raised its minimum wage to $19.08 an hour, causing angst among those who own businesses.
articles.abstract: In July, West Hollywood raised its minimum wage to $19.08 an hour, causing angst among those who own businesses.
articles.lead_paragraph: Josiah Citrin, the owner and chef of a Santa Monica restaurant with two Michelin stars, opened a new steakhouse a few months ago off the Sunset Strip. He is already concerned about whether the restaurant can survive.

articles.headline: Red Sea Attacks Pose Another Threat to Global Economy
articles.snippet: Already hampered by problems at the Panama Canal, shipping companies are now steering clear of the Suez Canal to avoid being attacked in the Red Sea.
articles.abstract: Already hampered by problems at the Panama Canal, shipping companies are now steering clear of the Suez Canal to avoid being attacked in the Red Sea.
articles.lead_paragraph: The wave of attacks against merchant ships in the Red Sea is forcing companies to send ships on longer routes and threatens to hurt an already wobbly global economy.
